Line 298: Line 298:
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> In a sign of unity, crowds in Tahrir Square are chanting "We are one, we are one" ahead of the prayers to be held at noon for those killed over the past 13 days of protest<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
Egyptian Christians held mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they are a part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> In a sign of unity, crowds in Tahrir Square are chanting "We are one, we are one" ahead of the prayers to be held at noon for those killed over the past 13 days of protest<ref name="aljazlive"/>. Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=06 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of 1 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> <!--notable or WP:TRIVIA-->In the midst of all of this, a young couple decided to get married. They planned to spend their honeymoon in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=In Egypt, a wedding amid the protests: 'Life shouldn't stop'|title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Washington Post|date=2011-02-07|accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
â
There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the train stations of El Ramel.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
There were also demonstrations continuing in Alexandria focuses around the train stations of El Ramel.<ref name="aljazlive"/> Several thousand anti-government protesters continued calling for the Egyptian president's resignation in Mansoura.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
Journalists continued to be targets of the ruling regime. [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
